title: On 24 May 2019, will the FTSE 100 Index closing value be higher than it was on 4 April 2019?
preds:
EDIT:  Post Mortem . . . . On this question, I not only died, but I was buried over 500 miles under ground zero!   Ouch!   So, what can I learn from this painful experience?  
#1  If I'm taking on a question in order to learn from it, I'd better bloody well study it, for goodness sakes! and not just guess!
#2  When I'm forecasting on a question about which I know almost nothing, I should make far more conservative forecasts
#3  I need to pay closer attention to daily activity and should adjust my forecast more often. Basically, given my current schedule and what's going on in my life, I should not have taken on this question!

UPD7: And the chance practically zero
UPD6: Highly unlikely with S&P closing down today 
UPD5: And up 
UPD4: Not much support with free fall now. 
UPD3: Serious correction on trade war. 
UPD2: Downgrade. Surprisingly huge disparity with S&P500. FTSE the worst performing lagging so far behind. 
UPD: Slightly higher as good alignment with forecast below / Good world data pushing up FTSE 100 is overweight in energy (17%) and miners (11%) sectors. With oil consolidated above $70 and commodities doing fairly well the upcoming earning season will be pretty good. This should push FTSE 100 towards support 7500-7600. With Brexit can kicked 6 months down the road £ will float around $1.30 which should avoid any currency risk surprises for earning reports. With dovish BoE and FED less worries for financials + spectacular rise in world equities since beginning of the year means financials (20%) will show good Q1. At least for now there is a chance to catch up with SP / Dow that are 10% higher than FTSE 100 on 52-week scale.

postmortem edit June 1: it appears results are being recalculated. As @Emil noted the result seemed inaccurate to me too. Still, i died on this one too, @Anneinak, and agree with your analysis.
There's a down-side to using an error-squared approach to calculating results: the occasional question where the forecaster and/or the crowd/median get it wrong dominates the scoreboard. Being 10% or 30% off the mark when the crowd is 20% off makes next to no difference, but being 90% or 70% off when the crowd is 80% sure does! I haven't done the math but imagine that forecasting conservatively (closer to 50% than the true probability) would pay off greatly in the long run because it's the questions with the low-probability outcome - like this one - which dominate.
I've not encountered error-squared evaluation before. Root-mean-square and mean-average-error are often used for evaluating forecasts for weather, e.g., tornados or solar power; perhaps they would give less punishing/lucky results for this game.

Edit: Post-mortem: Looks like the answer will be 'no'. Assuming that it is, I think I will have done better than I should have done if I had estimated base rate probabilities correctly. My statistical model uses base rates (in the form of historical daily movements) to build distributions for the eventual price level. However, this model assumes that volatility remains constant at its historical average. In reality, volatility varies. In particular, high volatility tends to follow high volatility. In other words, volatility is clustered. That is why economists use GARCH modeling which varies the volatility accordingly. In the case of the FTSE, the level dropped and stayed below the 4 April level, which led my model to assign a relatively high probability of 'no'. However, ideally my model would have used GARCH volatility to account for the fact that the FTSE could have easily bounced back up above the 4 April level. I am struggling to understand the scoring on this one. How could the crowd (median) have ~0.1? The question ran for approximately 50 days. The crowd was <50% for the right answer for about 40 days. Let's say it was at 50% for 40 days and 100% for the correct answer the last ten days. That would give a score of 0.5*(40/50) + 0*(10/50) = 0.4. Similarly I struggle to see how my score was ~0.7. Perhaps GJO may want to know about this? @amory10

Latest results of statistical model: 21%. However, the model underestimates the current volatility as it assumes volatility is what the historical average was. In contrast, the market has shown more volatility in the last week. Since volatile days tend to follow volatile days, the chance of a rebound above the 4 April level is higher than suggested by my model.

The crowd forecast has evened out to about 65% consistently and is more likely to be correct given the nearness of this forecast. The FTSE 100 has been and will be greatly impacted by Brexit - in early April the Brexit extension prompted a rise, so it’s likely that the more recent extension could do keep currency factors more stable. on April 4 the closing was 7,401.94, from there it’s been rising pretty steadily (except for the last few days.) Brexit isn’t the only factor, but the extension does support an increase from April barring unforeseen impacts. GDP growth is projected to increase slightly over the next year, but the U.S. China trade war could either positively or negatively impact all markets, depending on the outcome of a trade deal. http://web.b.ebscohost.com.proxyau.wrlc.org/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=66540440-bd21-4da1-ba4a-9578ae94fcd8%40sessionmgr104&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZSZzY29wZT1zaXRl#AN=26391957&db=buh https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/ftse.asp https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/UKX:IND https://www.intertrader.com/blog/five-key-factors-affecting-the-performance-of-the-ftse-100 https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-stocks/ftse-100-rises-as-pound-hit-by-brexit-deal-legal-opinion-idUKKBN1QT10I https://uk.reuters.com/article/britain-stocks/exporter-heavy-ftse-100-snaps-4-day-rally-as-potential-brexit-delay-lifts-pound-idUKL3N21L1RM https://www.bbc.com/news/live/business-48149045 https://www.dailyfx.com/forex/fundamental/article/special_report/2019/05/05/Dow-Jones-SP-500-DAX-30-and-FTSE-100-Price-Outlook.html

Two days after European elections, which seem likely to happen, and three weeks after the locals, so a strong indicator of attitudes to EU and likely actions after whatever action comes out about withdrawal/Article 50 etc. There could be a 'relief rally' if staying within the EU market because of the costs and problems of acting only under WTO rules, or whatever deal DT sees fit to impose (which can only be bad for the UK: he never offers any sort where he does not 'win', and he does not do 'win-win') . However, this direction will come late. Not impossible a General Election will be called at or about this date. This does not directly impact the markets but the election rhetoric might do, and could certainly unsettle announcements of major investment in FDI. Any further uncertainty or domestic problems - hate to say so, but Ireland, a hot summer in London, you name it - could affect confidence and a shift out of equities.

The more time passes, the more likely a *soft brexit* or *no brexit* solution will be negotiated, which will benefit the FTSE 100.

Just based on what I've read and seen on news sites.  Trade relations between the US and China are getting better, the US economy is chugging along and so this will have a ripple effect around the world.  Since Brexit has been postponed again, there is a sense of stability there for the foreseeable future.

According to BOE data, the option-implied probability is a hair above 50%, so that's a good base rate. The FTSE 100 is a cap-weighted index of the largest cap companies that trade on the London Stock Exchange. This is important, because not all of the companies are neither domiciled or earn a majority of their income in the UK. This is important, because it means the index is "a weak indicator of the UK economy" (Wikipedia).  For me, this means the question is about more than just Brexit - though ignoring Brexit would be foolish. The IMF, Survey of Professional Forecasters, and the WSJ Economic Survey have all reduced expectations for global growth, which would indicate volatile, but flat equity markets. The BOE meets on 5/2 - expected to hold rates constant, so there is not much on the horizon that would make me think one way or another. On the Brexit front, I don't think a deal will materialize in the next month. An extension would calm markets and (likely) lead to an increase. A no deal seems like a bad outcome for all parties so it seems even less likely. In that case. p(extension & FTSE higher) = 49%
p(no extension & FTSE higher) = 4.5% I'll keep an eye on those options markets!
Brexit will still be weighing on investor’s perception.
It's well above it's moving average of 7150 for the year and based on it's RSI of 64, it is closer to being overbought than oversold.
UK and Europe likely headed for recession.
The probability of America and China coming to the table will influence this

The stock market has grown very well for the last many years, and while a correction is expected sooner rather than later, I don't expect that to happen before May 24th which is why I'm pretty certain the market will continue its improvement.
General upward trend over time however we are late in the economic cycle and U.K. slowing down- time period matters, very hard to predict anything in a one month interval

Adjusting up slightly after considering the following possible baseline:
When comparing the closing values of 32 day windows (the remaining days until the question closes is about six weeks, assuming weekends as no trading days, but not considering holidays), 47% of these time windows had the index closing higher. With Brexit being delayed after the closing of the question, I see a bullish impact on the index and adjust slightly upwards.
It will rise a bit untill 5.24 due to the postponement of Brexit to Fall 2019.

Brexit has been delayed until October, there’s no need for the market to panic until then - money to be made. However recent manufacturing has increased in the UK due to potential shortages of goods after brexit (12 April) - shortages probably will not take place until at least October therefore demand will be reduced and production might go down too in the next few months so that might pull the index down a bit hence the 80%.

Extension past the end date of the question seems to become more likely:
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu/eu-to-agree-brexit-delay-but-france-pushes-for-conditions-idUSKCN1RK2HP

Several points:
FTSE 100 performance in last 6 years has always been positive in the same period. But, starting point in 2019 is the highest in the same period. Stockmarkets are surprisingly high: "Pessimism about the world economy has grown throughout 2019. Disappointing data, tumbling bond yields, the trade war between China and America and political crisis in Britain have all played a part. The only bright spot has been mostly buoyant stockmarkets." [1]. IMF has reviewed the prediction for 2019 GDP growth to 1.2% assuming a Brexit deal is achieved [2]. When WEO was previously published in October 2018, FTSE100 hit a 6-month low [3], with a 1.5% projection for 2019. Given the short period of time, a limited number of indicators will be published before May 24th (GDP annual growth rate 10/5, unemployment 16/4, 14/5 and inflation 17/, 22/5). BoE is not expected to change interest rates. All in all, limited impact in markets, supporting the assumed over valuation. Base then is slightly lower value of the index. 45%. Now, for Brexit, no-deal option seems unlikely, with an extension further May 24th the most likely outcome (say 90%, only limited for the European Parliament elections, something that PM May does not want). Extension would leave base as it is. Total, 90% of 45%, 41%. [1] https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/04/06/the-gloom-hanging-over-the-world-economy-is-confined-to-manufacturing
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/apr/09/imf-no-deal-brexit-risks-two-year-recession-uk-economic
[3] https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2018/oct/09/imf-uk-government-ease-austerity-growth-trade-wars-business-live

Immediate uncertainty about Brexit now has caused some share prices to drop. I believe that by 4 May 2019, the UK government will have agreed to a long extension to Brexit. This, in turn, will increase the prospect that the UK remains in the EU, which will cause the markets to rally.

In my base case the positive technical trend continues in the short term: 
https://www.investtech.com/main/market.php?CompanyID=44100003&product=5 Nobody wants a no-deal Brexit so I consider such outcome unlikely (~10%). So either extension or extension followed by a deal.
Other negative news might reverse the current trend, but within the short time frame such news is unlikely (~10%).
Small risk that even an extension or deal is negatively viewed by the market (~5%).
Magic 8 Ball says, 'Don't count on it.'

Scenarios considered to occur before 24 May:
- no deal Brexit (40% probability)
- deal Brexit (20%)
- extension (40%) In case of no deal, I see the no chance that the index will be higher. In case of a deal, I see 75% chance that it will be higher, and in case of an extension, I see 50% that it will be higher. Adding up the probabilities from the decision tree gets to the forecast.
doom and gloom exaggerated this gasbag makes a point on why remainers might vote leave if asked again: https://www.spectator.co.uk/2019/04/piers-morgan-why-as-a-former-remainer-id-now-back-leave/

Historical price movements imply a base rate of 50/50.  I am assuming progress on Brexit (at least some kind of resolution to the current uncertainty) is likely to lift the market further. Additionally, the index has been going up since January despite the Brexit commotion. On the other hand, an economic slowdown on the continent could have a bearish impact.
